text: hey everybody thomas joseph here and
today I'm tackling beans and typically
whenever you're using dried beans it's a
two-day process where you have to soak
the beans overnight and then you can
actually use them the next day but today
I'm going to show you the quick soaking
method so that you can have your beans
on the table in no time at all so I'm
going to spread out the beans on a
rimmed baking sheet like this and what
you really need to do is pick through
them make sure there are no little
stones if you have any broken pieces of
the beans just get rid of them because
they will cook unevenly
and once you've sorted through your
beans now you just need to give them a
quick rinse to rinse off any dirt that
may have accumulated on the beans so
right into a colander or a sieve and
some water swish them around in the
water cleaning them you can see how
cloudy the waters getting and that's
from all of the dust from the beans and
now once they're nicely rinsed place
them in a large pot and cover them with
a good amount of water I would say about
three inches over the top of the beans
turn up the heat and bring this up to a
boil now and what soaking does is it
hydrates the beans in a nice even way it
helps to soften the skin around the
beans and it cuts down the cooking time
by about half so you really want to make
sure that you do give the beans a soak
before you start cooking them now this
quick soaking method is really great
because it's done in about an hour and
you can carry on with cooking of the
beans so the beans have come up to a
boil I'm going to turn the heat off now
and I'm going to let these soak for
about one hour and then we'll be ready
to cook them now what you need to do is
drain them you can see here from the
soaking process that the beans have
actually doubled in size drain the beans
return them to the pot I'm going to
cover these with two inches of cold
water again and to this pot I'm gonna
add some aromatics
really give the beans a lot of flavor so
I have one white onion that I've cut
into quarters I have a head of garlic
gives really nice flavor a little bit of
carrot a little bit of celery and today
I'm using these beans for a wonderful
chili so I'm not going to add any herbs
but you could certainly do that so
medium heat bring this up to a low
simmer and let it simmer until the beans
are nice and tender and that can take
anywhere from 45 minutes to two hours
depending on which beans you're using so
just check and make sure that the
texture is just right for whatever dish
you're making so our beans have been
simmering and to test for doneness what
I like to do don't just try one bean try
a few make sure that they are nice and
tender you should be able to squeeze
them in your hands like that it should
be nice and creamy on the inside give it
a little bit of a taste and these are
good to go so I'm going to fish out the
aromatics and now our beans are ready to
transfer into the pot of chili that I
promised you all you have to do is
really stir them in at the end because
they're fully cooked and this would be
perfect for your Sunday gameday but you
could do anything with these beans you
can chill them down and you can throw
them into salads or you can make a
wonderful bean puree that you could
serve with pita chips or crudit√© so
their beans are really great if you are
going to cool them down what I suggest
you do is cool them in the cooking
liquid and store them in the cooking
liquid so that the beans don't dry out
or lose flavor so there you have it a
quick cooking method for beans it
doesn't take two days you can do it all
in one enjoy
you
